Features.Title: Animate with C#
Features.Description: Simply play an animation clip or a dedicated FlexMotion asset directly from your C# scripts.

Features.Title: Method chaining
Features.Description: Easily control how your animations are being played via expressive method chaining.

Features.Title: Easing-based transitions
Features.Description: Transitions between motion layers by setting a time and an [easing function](https://easings.net). Transitions can be changed and interrupted at will.

Features.Title: 1D/2D Motion blending
Features.Description: Blend multiple animations using handy weight computation methods or setting the weight values manually.

Features.Title: Avatar mask layers
Features.Description: Animate parts of your characters separately via Unity's avatar mask feature.

Features.Title: Pose
Features.Description: FlexMotion allows you to easily set a fixed pose on your character and then smoothly transition out to an animation.

Features.Title: Controllable update rate
Features.Description: Slow the update rate of your animations for stylistic or performance reasons.

Features.Title: Animation rigging
Features.Description: FlexMotion is compatible with the [Animation Rigging package](https://docs.unity3d.com/Packages/com.unity.animation.rigging@1.3/manual/index.html) via a simple component to add to your animated gameobject.

Features.Title: Animator features
Features.Description: FootIK, OnAnimatorIK, Events and root motion works out of the box. With some additional features for some of them.

Features.Title: Runtime layer mirroring
Features.Description: A motion layer can be mirrored individually at runtime. Works with Humanoid rig only (yet).

Features.Title: Time callbacks
Features.Description: Reacts to the end of an animation or a specific animation time via handy callbacks.
